recipes.label: Seek out a particular someone?
recipes.startdescription: Another evening at the Ecdysis. This time I am the one looking - I look above, past the human throng, where satins and pricking golden lights hang from the ceiling. There again, at the high balcony: the proprietor. She is looking, too.
recipes.description: Same as the last, she pays me no mind. I shuffle out out the club with all the rest. Is there truly nothing remarkable to be seen in me?

recipes.label: Seek out a particular someone?
recipes.startdescription: The traveller is again at the bar, writing in a book poorly bound with twine. He looks up only when I am standing over his shoulder. 'Ah, you again,' he wearily smiles. 'Something on your mind?'
recipes.description: He hmms thoughtfully, but his eyes look bothered - annoyed, even - and swiftly retreats to the innards of his book. Perhaps now is not the time.

recipes.label: Seek out a particular someone?
recipes.startdescription: The haze of that previous night is gone, but the gaunt-eyed artist from before is once again at the Ecdysis. He recognizes me with a wave, and I him. 'We never did finish our conversation about art,' he drones, already the thrall of some affective substance. 'Shall we resume?' The man holds out that long pipe again, sweetly smouldering.
recipes.description: The herb in the pipe is different, but no less amiable to me. My throat catches on the vapours. The gaunt-eyed man is yelling - or is he laughing? - and the room, somehow, begins to sweat. When I come down from my stupor, I am home. I am unsure of how that is so.

recipes.label: Seek out a particular someone?
recipes.startdescription: 'Bonsoir,' says the cyclopean Frenchman. The two of us are again at the club's bar, meditating away from the noisesome stage. I ask him for his knife; I ask to play his game again, and he obliges. 'You still want to know about my eye, then? Very well. I can call it at ten this time, if you'd like.'
recipes.description: The Frenchman tuts, grinning again, and presses his napkin to my bleeding finger. 'I had a comrade who lost his ring finger trying to beat me at this,' he chides, folding the knife back into his coat. 'The one thing you two share is a very admirable sense of persistence.'
